content.body: I left a comment on your URL merge request with what seems to be a related case that is currently failing locally
How does chromium track intermittently failing tests? Maybe I'm just using wrong keywords when trying to find some information from issues.chromium.org
annevk: you might know if webkit is doing something like that
content.formatted_body: annevk: you might know if webkit is doing something like that

content.body: The background is that it might be useful to see if some tests are failing in multiple engines - especially if the tests are written in a way where they rely on certain scheduling even though the spec doesn't require that.
Shannon Booth: cool, thanks for taking a look.
content.formatted_body: Shannon Booth: cool, thanks for taking a look.

content.body: smaug: in LayoutTests there's multiple TestExpectations files (one global and then one per platform) where we track skipping tests for flaky reasons. No standardized annotation I'm afraid, but if you have a file name it should be easyish to find there.
content.formatted_body: smaug: in LayoutTests there's multiple TestExpectations files (one global and then one per platform) where we track skipping tests for flaky reasons. No standardized annotation I'm afraid, but if you have a file name it should be easyish to find there.

content.body: smaug: https://github.com/WebKit/WebKit/blob/main/LayoutTests/TestExpectations (note that some of the things that are globally skipped are enabled on specific ports, we use that for certain types of form control tests for instance)
content.formatted_body: smaug: https://github.com/WebKit/WebKit/blob/main/LayoutTests/TestExpectations (note that some of the things that are globally skipped are enabled on specific ports, we use that for certain types of form control tests for instance)

content.body:
> <@smaug:mozilla.org> How does chromium track intermittently failing tests? Maybe I'm just using wrong keywords when trying to find some information from issues.chromium.org

If you search for the filename of the test, it will show up if it's in TestExpectations
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @smaug:mozilla.org
How does chromium track intermittently failing tests? Maybe I'm just using wrong keywords when trying to find some information from issues.chromium.org
If you search for the filename of the test, it will show up if it's in TestExpectations

content.body: On source.chromium.org
ah, thanks
jarhar: and there is something to hint about intermittent issues?
content.formatted_body: jarhar: and there is something to hint about intermittent issues?

content.body: Perhaps [ Failure Pass ] ?
If the test is flaky then it is almost certainly listed in TestExpectations. If it's in TestExpectations anywhere, then we most likely ignore the test basically
Failure pass at the end of it means that we accept failure or pass results from the test
Apparently "pass" is implied though which is unfortunate
Timeout is another thing that can go in the square brackets

If the test is failing consistently and isn't flaky or timing out, then instead of being in TestExpectations we might have another file next to it that ends with -expected.txt which contains the failing test cases/assertions

ok, and [one](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/TestExpectations;l=8271?q=beforematch-scroll-to-text-fragment.html) of the tests I was looking at earlier today is there ðŸ™‚
content.formatted_body: ok, and one of the tests I was looking at earlier today is there ðŸ™‚
